required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.official_title: Muscle Performance and Walking in Cerebral Palsy: Short-burst Interval Training

collaborator.agency: Louisiana State University Health Sciences Center in New Orleans

brief_summary.textblock: This study examines the effect of short burst interval treadmill training in ambulatory children with cerebral palsy. Half the sample will receive 20 sessions of training over 4 weeks, while half will receive the training over 10 weeks.

detailed_description.textblock:
Ambulatory children with cerebral palsy (CP) experience activity limitations which negatively influence their ability to physically participate in day to day life. Therefore, these children are at greater risk for inactivity and functional decline with age. In contrast, typically developing (TD) children engage in short bursts of intense physical activity interspersed with varying intervals of low and moderate intensity within their natural environment. These physical activity patterns are very different from adult patterns Despite these inherent differences, locomotor treadmill training (LTT) protocols designed to improve walking activity in children with CP simulate adult protocols, consisting of continuous low to moderate walking endurance activity. Body weight supported or robot assisted LTT is based on the underlying premise of modifying neural circuitry via spinal pathways. However, this type of training has not been shown to be more effective than other comparable interventions and presents with significant fiscal and logistical barriers to clinical translation.
This study will determine the effect of short-burst interval LTT without body weight support on the primary outcomes of walking performance and capacity and the secondary outcomes of day-to-day mobility based participation in children with CP with functional walking limitations. To identify key muscular mechanisms associated with improved walking mobility, the investigators will examine the effects of short-burst interval LTT on quadriceps muscle performance and architecture. Secondarily, the study team will collect preliminary data on two LTT dosing frequencies.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Pre/post intervention design with participants randomized to two different frequency of intervention
study_design_info.masking_description: Muscle function assessor masked to frequency group, Muscle architecture captured via ultrasound Community walking activity collected by accelerometry, thus non-human data collection

primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline to 6 weeks post SBLTT
primary_outcome.description: Average stride per day as measured by StepWatch accelerometry

primary_outcome.measure: Change in Community Walking Performance Intensity
primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline to 6 weeks post SBLTT
primary_outcome.description: Average Strides/day > 30 strides/min as measured by StepWatch accelerometry

primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline to immediately post SBLTT and 6 weeks followup
primary_outcome.description: Walking speed as measured by 10 meter walk test

primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline to 6 weeks post SBLTT
primary_outcome.description: Distance walked during the One Minute Walk Test

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in walking performance High versus Low frequency SBLTT groups
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline to 6 weeks post SBLTT between high and low frequency SBLTT groups
secondary_outcome.description: Average stride per day as measured by StepWatch accelerometry

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in walking endurance- High versus Low frequency SBLTT groups
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline to 6 weeks post SBLTT between high and low frequency SBLTT groups
secondary_outcome.description: Distance walked during the One Minute Walk Test

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in walking capacity High versus Low frequency SBLTT groups
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline to 6 weeks post SBLTT between high and low frequency SBLTT groups
secondary_outcome.description: Walking speed as measured by 10 meter walk test

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline to 6 weeks post SBLTT
secondary_outcome.description: Knee extensor muscle power - isotonic muscle power as measured by Biodex testing

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline to 6 week post SBLTT
secondary_outcome.description: Knee extensor muscle strength - isometric muscle strength as measured by Biodex testing

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline to 6 week post SBLTT
secondary_outcome.description: Rectus femoris mid thigh cross-sectional area as measured by 2D B Mode Ultrasound

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline to 6 week post SBLTT
secondary_outcome.description: Rectus femoris mid thigh fascicle length as measured by 2D B Mode Ultrasound

arm_group.description: All participants receive short burst interval treadmill training for a total of 20 sessions. They are randomized to receive it either 5x/week for 4 weeks or 2x/week for 10 weeks.

intervention.intervention_name: Short Burst Interval Locomotor Treadmill Training (SBLTT)
intervention.description: SBLTT consists of interval training consisting of short-bursts (30 seconds) of vigorous intensity locomotor treadmill training (LTT) alternating with low to moderate intensity LTT.,

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Ambulatory children with cerebral palsy Spasticity primary movement disorder Bilateral motor impairment (Diplegia) Gross Motor Function Classification System Levels II and III
Exclusion Criteria:
- undergone orthopedic or neurosurgery less than 12 months prior injection therapies (phenol, botulinum toxin) less than 3 months prior
